column2: So I told Carl, \xc2\x91Nobody, no matter how famous their parents are,\nnobody is allowed to climb on the dinosaur.\xc2\x92 But of course this went in one ear and\nout.....'
I love how he cares so much about stuff. If I squint I can pretend\nhe\xc2\x92s Alan Alda.'
Oh good, another dinosaur story. When are those gonna become extinct?'
If I was a superhero who could fly and be invisible, that\nwould be the best.'
What does Rachel see in this guy? I love Rachel. I wish she was my\nwife.'
Who\xc2\x92s singing?'
Hey. When you guys were kids and you played Happy Days, who were\nyou? I was always Richie.'
I was always Joanne.'
Question. Was ah, \xc2\x91Egg the Gellers!\xc2\x92 the war cry of your\nneighbourhood?'
Ewww! Oh! It\xc2\x92s the Mattress King!'
Booo!!'
(to Janice) Don\xc2\x92t look honey. Change the channel! Change the\nchannel!'
Wait! Wait! I wanna see this. After I divorce him, half of that kingdom\nis gonna be mine.'

(on TV) \xc2\x91Despair fills the mattress showroom. My kingdom
is suddenly without a queen. I\xc2\x92m so depressed I\xc2\x92m going to slash... my prices!!
Check it out! Four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set! I\xc2\x92m going medieval on
prices!'
What a wank!'
Oh, I cannot believe he\xc2\x92s using our divorce to sell mattresses.'
I know! And four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set, who cares about\nthe divorce, those babies will sell themselves. (they all stare at her) And I\xc2\x92m\nappalled for you by the way.'
(on TV) I\xc2\x92m close. I\xc2\x92m cheap. I\xc2\x92m the king.'
\xc2\x91Okay. (listens) Okay, daddy we\xc2\x92ll see you tomorrow night.\n(listens) Okay bye-bye.\xc2\x92 (hangs up)'
We?'
Are ah, having dinner with my Dad tomorrow night, I hope that\xc2\x92s\nokay.'
Oh shoot, tomorrow\xc2\x92s not so good, I\xc2\x92m supposed to um, fall off\nthe Empire State building and land on a bicycle with no seat. Sorry.'
Ross, my father doesn\xc2\x92t hate you.'
Please, he refers to me as \xc2\x91wethead\xc2\x92.'

But honey he calls everybody by a nickname! Okay, look, I know, all
right, just one dinner, please, just one night for me, please. I just want him to love you
like I do. (Ross looks at her) All right, well not exactly like I do, but, but, if you do
come to dinner, I\xc2\x92ll love you like I do in that black thing that you like.'
(leaning in) I\xc2\x92ll go.'
Fine.'
Thank you.'
Hi Gunther.'
Yeah, we\xc2\x92ll see!'
(entering) Hey, you guys!'
Hey!'
Guess what?'
What?'
I got a gig!'
Yay!!'
See, that\xc2\x92s why I could never be an actor. Because I can\xc2\x92t\nsay gig.'
Yeah, I can\xc2\x92t say croissant. (realises) Oh my God!'
What\xc2\x92s the part?'
Well, it\xc2\x92s not a part, no. I\xc2\x92m teaching acting for soap operas\ndown at the Learning Extension.'
Come on! That\xc2\x92s great.'
Wow!'
Yeah, yeah. It\xc2\x92s like my chance to give something back to the acting\ncommunity.'
Y\xc2\x92know your probably not allowed to sleep with any of your students.'
(glares at him) I know!'
Ugh! I don\xc2\x92t know Monica. It feels funny just being here. I mean if\nyou buy a bed from Janice\xc2\x92s ex-husband, that\xc2\x92s like betraying Chandler.'
Not at these prices.'

(sees a little kid playing with a race car bed) (to kid) Hi. Y'know in\nEngland this car would be on the other side of the store. (the kid just stares at her, and\nshe makes the \xc2\x91that went right over your head\xc2\x92 motion) Woo!"
(lying down on a mattress) Oh! Ohhhhh! Oh! Phoebe, come here. Aw, this\nis my new bed. You gotta feel this bad boy.'
Eh, Monica it, it feels so weird, y'know, Chandler\xc2\x92s your friend...\n(hops onto the bed) Oh! Oh my God! Aw, all right take this bed, you can make other\nfriends."

Good evening. I\xc2\x92m Mr. Tribbiani. And I will be teaching acting for
soap operas. Now um, on my first day as (proudly) Dr. Drake Remoray on Days of Our
Lives, (looks for a reaction from his students, and gets none.) I learned that one of
the most important things in soap opera acting is reacting, this does not mean acting
again, it means, you don\xc2\x92t have a line, but someone else just did. And it goes like
this. (looks all intense for a moment and then gasps, the students cheer him) Thanks,
thanks, a lot. Oh, by the way, before I forget to work in soap operas some of you will
have to become much more attractive. All right, moving right along.'
Hi!'
Hey! Ooh! How was teaching last night?'
Oh it was great. Yeah, you get to say stuff like, \xc2\x92Hey, the bell\ndoesn\xc2\x92t dismiss you, I dismiss you.\xc2\x92'
Ooooh, nice.'
Oh, and guess what, I got an audition for All My Children.'
Oh, yay!'
Yeah, it\xc2\x92s this great part, this boxer named Nick. And I\xc2\x92m so,\nso right for it, y'know, he\xc2\x92s just like me. Except he\xc2\x92s a boxer, and has an evil\ntwin."
Oh. (goes and answers the door and there is this huge black\ndelievery guy.) '
Dom da-da dom! Here ye! Here ye! Delivery from the Mattress King. (to\nPhoebe) You Miss Geller?'
Okay.'
Sign here. (hands her a clipboard)'
Oh, do I have a middle name. All right Monica Velula Geller. It\xc2\x92s\nthat bedroom there. (points to Monica\xc2\x92s room)'
Hey, Monica bought a bed from the Mattress King?'
Yeah, so please, please, please, don\xc2\x92t say anything to Chandler.'
You want me to lie to Chandler?'
Is that a problem?'
No.'
Oh, hey, hey Nick the boxer let\xc2\x92s see what you got. All right ya,\nput \xc2\x91em up. Come on. (they start shadow boxing)'
Hey, you\xc2\x92re ah, pretty good at this.'
Yeah, well I had to learn, I was staying at the Y and some off the young\nmen weren\xc2\x92t acting Christian enough.'
Ahh!'
Hey now!'
Hey!!! Oww!! And I\xc2\x92m bleeding.'
Oh! Oh! Oh!'
Okay, great.'
Wow! And I\xc2\x92m a vegetarian! All right, all right, well I\xc2\x92m\nsorry, we\xc2\x92ll put some ice on it. '
Okay.'
\xc2\x91Kay, put your head back.'
All right. I can\xc2\x92t see.'
All right, I have ya. Oh God.'
Which bedroom do ya want it in Miss Geller?'
Oh, it\xc2\x92s the compulsively neat one by the window, okay.'
Gotcha. (he and his helper walk in carrying the racecar bed.)'
Hi Daddy!'
This where they put it? What, there no table available in the\nkitchen! Hello, baby.'
You remember Ross.'
Um-hmm.'
Nice to see you again Dr. Green. '
So! (they both try to sit next to Rachel but Dr. Green is\nsuccessful.) (to Ross) How\xc2\x92s the library?'
Ugh, museum.'
What happened to the library?'
There never was a library. I mean there are libraries, its just that I ah,\nI never worked at one.'
You know what\xc2\x92s really good here, the lobster. What do you say\nshall I just order three.'
Yeah, if you\xc2\x92re really hungry. (Dr. Green stares at him) It was a\njoke, I made a joke.'
Yeah, actually Daddy Ross is allergic to lobster.'
What kind of person is allergic to lobster? I guess the kind of\nperson that works at a library.'
It\xc2\x92s not a library...'

(interrupting him) I know!! It\xc2\x92s a museum! What, you\xc2\x92re the\nonly one around here who can make a joke! At least mine was funny. Ah, waiter, we will\nhave two lobsters and a menu. (nods at Ross, and mouths I don\xc2\x92t know to the waiter.)'
So, Dr. Green, how\xc2\x92s the old boat.'
They found rust. You know what rust does to a boat?'
It gives it a nice antiquey look.'
(he stares at Ross) Rust, is boat cancer, Ross.'
Wow. I\xc2\x92m sorry, when I was a kid I lost a bike to that. (Rachel\ngiggles at that)'
Excuse me for a moment, will you please, I want to say good night to\nthe Levines, before we go.'
Okay.'
Okay! (picks up a knife and pretends to stab his heart.)'
Aw honey stop! It\xc2\x92s not that bad.'
Yeah. (sees the bill) Op! Uh-oh! I think your Dad must\xc2\x92ve added\nwrong. He only tipped like four percent.'
Yeah. That\xc2\x92s Daddy.'
That\xc2\x92s Daddy?! But doesn\xc2\x92t it bother you? You\xc2\x92re a\nwaitress.'
Yes, it bothers me Ross, but y'know if he was a regular at the coffee\nhouse, I\xc2\x92d be serving him sneezers."
So?'
So. Ross, I\xc2\x92ve bugged him about this a million times, he\xc2\x92s not\ngonna change.'
You really serve people sneezers?'
Well um, I don\xc2\x92t.'
You kids ready?'
Thanks again, Dr. Green.'
All right.'
Oh, wait, wait, wait, wait, I think I forgot my receipt.'
Oh, ah, you don\xc2\x92t need that.'
Why not?'
The carbon, it\xc2\x92s messy, I mean it gets on your fingers and causes,\nthe, the ah, night blindness.'
(gets his receipt and notices the twenty) What is this? Who put a\ntwenty down here? Huh?'
Oh, yeah, that would be me, um, I have, I have a problem I-I tip way too\nmuch, way, way, too much, it\xc2\x92s a sickness really.'
Yeah it is, it is. (to Ross) We really, really have to do something\nabout that.'
I know.'
Excuse me, you think I\xc2\x92m cheap?'
Oh Daddy, no he didn\xc2\x92t mean anything by that, he really\ndidn\xc2\x92t.'
Nothing I do means anything, really.'

This is nice. I pay two hundred dollars for dinner, you put down
twenty, and you come out looking like Mr. Big Shot. You really want to be Mr. Big Shot?
Here, I\xc2\x92ll tell you what, you pay the whole bill, Mr. Big Shot, all right. (rips up
the bill, and throws it at Ross, then leaves)'
Well Mr. Big Shot is better than \xc2\x91wethead\xc2\x92.'

Okay, some tricks of the trade. Now, I\xc2\x92ve never been able to cry as
an actor, so if I\xc2\x92m in a scene where I have to cry, I cut a hole in my pocket, take a
pair of tweezers, and just start pulling. Or ah, or, let\xc2\x92s say I wanna convey that
I\xc2\x92ve just done something evil. That would be the basic \xc2\x91I have a fishhook in my
eyebrow and I like it\xc2\x92 (Does it by raising one eyebrow, and showing off the pretend
fishhook.) Okay, let\xc2\x92s say I\xc2\x92ve just gotten bad news, well all I do there is try
and divide 232 by 13. (looks all confused) And that\xc2\x92s how it\xc2\x92s done. Great soap
opera acting tonight everybody, class dismissed.'
Hey, Mr. Trib.'
Hey-hey.'
Guess what, I got an audition!'
Awww, one of my students got an audition. I\xc2\x92m so proud.'
I was wondering if you would consider coaching me for it?'
You bet! What\xc2\x92s the part?'
Oh it\xc2\x92s great, it\xc2\x92s a role on All My Children, Nick\nthe boxer.'
You had to do it, didn\xc2\x92t you? You couldn\xc2\x92t just leave it\nalone.'
Four percent. Okay. I tip more than that when there\xc2\x92s a bug in my\nfood.'
Ross, tonight was about the two of you getting along. (Ross groans and\nrubs his neck) Oh, would you just see my chiropractor, already.'
Yeah, I\xc2\x92m gonna go to a doctor who went to school in a mini-mall.'
Hey Pheebs, what are you doing?'

I\xc2\x92m, I\xc2\x92m freaking out! Monica kinda trusted me with something\nand she shouldn\xc2\x92t have! All right, I haven\xc2\x92t lived here in a while, so I have to\nask you something. Does Monica still turn on the lights in her bedroom?'
Um. yeah.'
I am soo dead. (goes to Monica\xc2\x92s room)'
All right, look, here\xc2\x92s the bottom line Ross, this is fixable, if\nwe act fast, okay. So, I\xc2\x92ll invite him to brunch tomorrow and you can make nice.'
Look, honey, I have tried to make nice, it doesn\xc2\x92t work.'
Okay, look, Ross, I realise that my Father is difficult, but that\xc2\x92s\nwhy you have got to be the bigger man here.'

Look sweetie, I could be the bigger man, I could be the biggest man, I\ncould be a big, huge, giant man, and it still wouldn\xc2\x92t make any difference, except\nthat I could pick your Father up and say \xc2\x91Like me! Like me tiny doctor!\xc2\x92'
Okay, well can\xc2\x92t you just try it one more time Ross? For me? For\nme?'
Rachel one brunch is not gonna solve anything. You gotta face it, okay\nwe\xc2\x92re never gonna get along.'

Okay, well you are just gonna have too, okay. Because I already got a\nMother and a Father who cannot stay in the same room together, okay, I don\xc2\x92t wanna\nhave to have a separate room for you too!! (starts to cry)'
Okay, okay, okay. (hugs her) I\xc2\x92ll get the bagels.'
(sees the bed) What\xc2\x92s this?'
Isn\xc2\x92t it cool! Varoom! Varoom!'
This is not the bed I ordered!'
I know, you must\xc2\x92ve won like a contest or something! '
Phoebe!'
Why is this car in my bedroom?'
I\xc2\x92m sorry, okay, I-I wasn\xc2\x92t looking, and the store says that\nthey won\xc2\x92t take it back because you signed for it...'
When did I sign for it?'
When I was you! Y'know what, it\xc2\x92s all Joey\xc2\x92s fault,\n\xc2\x91cause he left his nose open!"
Did you make brownies today?'
Knock, knock.'
(to Phoebe) Quick, take off your dress, he won\xc2\x92t notice the bed.'
Hey, I\xc2\x92m going for sushi does anybody want.. (enters and sees the\nbed) Whoa-whoa, somebody missed the off ramp.'
It\xc2\x92s Monica\xc2\x92s bed. What?'
Okay. (to Monica) It\xc2\x92s a racecar.'
So. This has always been Monica\xc2\x92s bed, what you\xc2\x92re just\nnoticing now, how self-involved are you?'
Okay, well it this bed isn\xc2\x92t new, how come there is plastic on\nthe mattress?'
Sometimes I have bad dreams. (starts to break down, and Phoebe offers\nher, her hand to comfort her.)'
Look, I just saw my best friends brains smeared across the canvas,\nthat\xc2\x92s not gonna be me, not me.'
Wow! That was good. That was...(points to his pocket) Tweezers?'
No.'
Whoa. That was really good.'
Thanks, any suggestions?'
You told him to play the boxer gay!!'
Well, I-I might\xc2\x92ve said supergay.'
You totally screwed him over.'
Joey, you\xc2\x92re this guy\xc2\x92s teacher. I mean how could you do this?'
Because, Monica, the guy\xc2\x92s so good, and I really, really want this\npart.'
Well, if you really, really want it, then it\xc2\x92s okay.'
(opening the door) Hi Daddy.'
Baby. Ross.'
Dr. Green. How are you? (offers his hand, and Dr. Green puts his scarf on\nit.)'
Thanks for dinner last night.'
Thank you for teaching me a valuable lesson.'
Nice hair. What\xc2\x92d ya do? Swim here?'
(to Rachel) Okay, that\xc2\x92s it, I can\xc2\x92t take it anymore.'
What? What? He\xc2\x92s interested in you. He-he likes your hair, he just\nwants to know how you got here.'
Oh, please. Sweetie it\xc2\x92s hopeless, okay, I\xc2\x92m just gonna go.\n(starts to leave rubbing his neck)'
What?!'
Look, look I\xc2\x92m sorry. It\xc2\x92s just that....'
Ross? What\xc2\x92s with the neck?'
He\xc2\x92s got this thing. And I keep telling him to go to my\nchiropractor...'
You\xc2\x92re still going to that chiropractor, that man couldn\xc2\x92t\nget into medical school in Extapa!'
Thank you! That\xc2\x92s what I keep saying.'
Excuse me, Dr. Bobby happens to be an excellent doctor.'
Uh.'
Wait a minute, his name is Dr. Bobby?'
Well that\xc2\x92s his last name.'
And his first name.'
He\xc2\x92s Bobby Bobby?'
It\xc2\x92s Robert Bobby.'
Oh.'
And um, excuse me, he helps me.'
Oh-ho please. Ask her how?'
What do you need help for?'
With my alignment. I\xc2\x92ve got one leg shorter than the other.'
Oh God!'
Argue with that.'
What? It\xc2\x92s true, my right leg is two inches shorter.'
Come on! You\xc2\x92re just titling! (to Ross) Her legs are fine!'
I know that!'
So, why do you let her go to a chiropractor for?'
I\xc2\x92m sorry, let her?'
What can I do, she doesn\xc2\x92t listen to me about renter\xc2\x92s insurance\neither.'
Wait a minute, you don\xc2\x92t have renter\xc2\x92s insurance?!'
No.'
Well what if somebody steals something? How are you gonna run after\nhim with one leg shorter than the other?!'
Hey, would you ah, would you like some juice?'
I\xc2\x92d love some juice. Thanks.'
Okay. (to Rachel) Wow! This is going so well. Did you see us? Did you see?'
Yeah honey, I\xc2\x92m standing right there! Why didn\xc2\x92t you just tell\nhim about the mole I haven\xc2\x92t got checked yet.'
Excellent!'

(sadly) There will come a time in each of your careers when you\xc2\x92ll
have a chance to screw over another soap opera actor. I had such an opportunity in the
recent, present. And I\xc2\x92m ashamed to say that I took it, I advised a fellow actor to
play a role, homosexually. Yeah, we both auditioned for the part, and uh, as it turned
out, they ah, they liked the stupid gay thing and cast him. And now, he\xc2\x92s got a two
year contract opposite Susan Luchhi, the first lady of daytime television, and me, me
I\xc2\x92m stuck here teaching a bunch of people, most of whom are too ugly to even be on
TV. I\xc2\x92m sorry, I\xc2\x92m sorry, I\xc2\x92m sorry. (he gets a huge round of applause from
his students.) Thank you.'
Uh, may I help you?'
Yeah, I talked to you on the phone, I\xc2\x92m the lady that got stuck\nwith the racecar bed.'
Look, it\xc2\x92s like I told you, there\xc2\x92s nothing I can do. You\nsigned for it, Monica Velula Geller.'
All right, Jester man, look we wanna see the king.'
Nobody sees the king!'
Oh-ho-kay, I\xc2\x92m talking to the king. (starts to go to a back room)'
Hey! You can\xc2\x92t go back there!'
Oh my God.'

Varrrrrroom! Hey! Watch it lady! Varrrrrrrrrrom! (makes a screeching
sound as he pretends to stomp on the brakes.) Hey-hey good lookin\xc2\x92! (honks the
bed\xc2\x92s little horn on the steering wheel.) Varrrrrrrrroom. (notices Rachel and stops)
All right, I\xc2\x92ll leave. My bed\xc2\x92s so boring.'
